origination.corpname: Hannah and Lay Company (Traverse City, Mich.)

did.unittitle: Hannah and Lay Company (Traverse City, Mich.) Records 1846-1931
did.abstract: Lumber and mercantile company of Chicago, Illinois and Traverse City, Michigan. Business records include minutes, correspondence, and financial ledgers, daybooks, and journals.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred from the Burton Historical Collection (donor no. 1531) which had originally received the records from the company.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Hannah and Lay Company (Traverse City, Mich.) Records , Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Hannah and Lay Company began as a partnership between Perry Hannah, Albert Tracy Lay, and James Morgan in the burgeoning Chicago lumber trade around the middle of the nineteenth century. At first the company purchased lumber from ships that docked in the Chicago harbor. Hoping to eliminate middle-man profits, the partners hoped to operate their own mill. After some investigation, Hannah and Morgan in 1851 decided to purchase a inactive sawmill in the Grand Traverse Bay area of Michigan as well as surrounding timber-rich acreage. The Hannah and Lay development would provide the foundation for city of Traverse City. The company under the management of Hannah acquired additional property totaling by 1886 45,000 acres of timber land. With the great demand for lumber, the company flourished, but also diversifying its business to include Great Lakes shipping, real estate acquisition, flour milling, banking, and storekeeping. In 1883, the company split into two separate corporate entities: Hannah Lay and Company and Hannah Lay Mercantile Company. For many years, Perry Hannah and Albert Tracy Lay alternated each year in the supervision of their Chicago and Traverse City operations. Eventually, Lay would remain in Chicago and Hannah would make Traverse City his permanent home. Recognizing that the boom in timber would not last forever, Hannah in 1886 wisely sold off his timber interests and devoted his energies to the company's mercantile and related operations. Hannah died in 1904, but the company would continue until 1931 when the Traverse City assets of the company were liquidated.

scopecontent.p: The records of Hannah Lay Company have been divided into two series: Hannah and Lay Company Business Records and Hannah and Lay Mercantile Company.
The history of the arrangement and appraisal of the Hannah and Lay records has been fully described in an article in the American Archivist (Jan. 1976) by Larry Steck and Francis Blouin.

did.unittitle: Hannah and Lay Company Business Records

scopecontent.p: The Hannah and Lay Company Business Records series dates from 1846 to 1931 and documents both the operation of the company in Chicago and in Traverse City. The series includes correspondence, annual reports, and financial journals, daybooks, and ledgers. In addition, there are records detailing the acquisition of properties in the Grand Traverse area, shipping records, and records of the company store in Traverse City.

did.unittitle: Lumber Camp and Boarding House Accounts book 1858-1861
Inventory no. 2, Traverse City Village Lots, improved and unimproved 1891-1895
Ledger of Traverse City Land Sold 1889-1900
Plat Book, Traverse City, Perry Hannah's Additions 1892-1914
Survey data drawn from first Grand Traverse property owned by HLC 1887

scopecontent.p: The second series - Hannah and Lay Mercantile Company -- details the diversification of the company into the retail business, and includes annual reports, correspondence, sales reports, financial records, invoices, and related materials. The series dates from 1883 to 1931.

did.unittitle: Annual Reports of General Manager and/or Secretary

scopecontent.p: Streetfront view of store and interior photo showing displays and arrangement of merchandise.
